title: United States Government: Recommended Grade Level: Grades 11 or 12
subject: Social Studies (2014-2020)

document.title: Indiana Department of Education College and Career Readiness

6F1B367F94FD4D9B84E715C34FC99DCB.description:
Use information from a variety of resources to describe and discuss current American political issues.
(History, Economics, Geography)

1EDB02411436412CB4A09DE147C9FE0B.description:
Describe opportunities available to individuals to contribute to the well-being of their communities and
participate responsibly in the political process at local, state and national levels of government.

4EA77B98B14A4C0BA957644E79E677A6.description:
Explain how citizens in the United States participate in public elections as voters and supporters of
candidates for public office.

8E3F31321115426299C5DF83CE438CB3.description:
Explain and give examples of important citizen actions that monitor and influence local, state, and national
government as individuals and members of interest groups.

D8523BC758C14532B2E68EC1BC9A3F06.description:
Identify when it is constitutional for our government to limit the rights of individuals and explain the reasons
why the government would want to do this. (History)

0C75C68145544766AB7B8420A110B0A2.description:
Identify and describe the civil and constitutional rights found in the United States Constitution and Bill of
Rights and expanded by decisions of the United States Supreme Court; analyze and evaluate landmark
cases of the United States Supreme Court concerning civil rights and liberties of individuals.

F4E097A51B8441848D4E897ACDA156DE.description: Discuss the individual’s legal obligation to obey the law, serve as a juror, and pay taxes.

99EAA09EFE7342A1B703DFFA7DA77F5F.description:
Analyze the roles and responsibilities of citizens in Indiana and the United States. (Individuals, Society and
Culture)

AEB97D3DFAE44B8ABDE7B2988F7DB9B0.description:
Define the legal meaning of citizenship in the United States; identify the requirements for citizenship in the
United States and residency in Indiana and understand the criteria used for attaining both.

E048707425B84CEEBA9AB8408AEC288A.description: Roles of Citizens in the United States

6A994EC533004165BE80ECD60206F283.description:
Discuss specific foreign policy issues that impact local community and state interests. (Economics;
Individuals, Society and Culture)

E7CA630A2D6049589BFC07C43C3760E7.description:
Identify and explain world issues, including political, cultural, demographic, economic and environmental
challenges that affect the United States foreign policy in specific regions of the world.

89BD576616594DA2ADD28D472BDEFE41.description:
Examine the influence individuals, businesses, labor, and other organizations, interest groups, and public
opinion has on United States foreign policy. (Economics)

B2701C3860DE483588538029F37AFD17.description:
Identify and describe strategies available to the United States government to achieve foreign policy
objectives. (Economics; Geography; History; Individuals, Society and Culture)

42CB87D583284B6CA6DCBBA0E267F36A.description:
Analyze powers the United States Constitution gives to the executive, legislative and judicial branches of
government in the area of foreign affairs.

19EBE075C99B49EF977E2FA44A27F52E.description:
Provide examples of governmental and non-governmental international organizations and explain their role
in international affairs.

9C73E5C08360403083532B7DA55B9752.description:
Analyze reasons for conflict among nations, such as competition for resources and territory, differences in
ideology, and religious or ethnic conflicts.

0C7962A0E69B428C9EFD94C82325B25B.description: Describe how different governments interact in world affairs. (Individuals, Society and Culture)

E5B60DEC6C944A89B3FA1B4DAC1C5BBB.description:
Compare and contrast governments throughout the world with the United States government in terms of
source of the government’s power.

488FD2FEC04345BDB6861A5999017D63.description: The Relationship of the United States to Other Nations in World Affairs

844AFB737A21438FAD5529BBA0E9591A.description: Describe the influence of the media and technology on public opinion and public policy.

D6BF4B90200141B399D96A1588C54F2B.description:
Identify the historical significance of and analyze decisions by the United States Supreme Court about the
constitutional principle of federalism in cases such as McCulloch v. Maryland (1819), Alden v. Maine (1999)
and the denial of certiorari for the Terri Schiavo case (2005). (History; Individuals, Society and Culture)
certiorari: a writ from a high court to a low court requesting a transcript of the proceedings of a case for
review

5836B85B5CD3487D891B44B9096A8143.description:
Identify the historical significance of and analyze decisions by the United States Supreme Court about the
constitutional principles of separation of powers and checks and balances in such landmark cases as
Marbury v. Madison (1803), Baker v. Carr (1962), United States v. Nixon (1974), Clinton v. City of New
York (1998) and Bush v. Gore (2000).

E094E211B79A4D72AAB84D2DCFE190E7.description:
Identify the role and development of special interest groups in politics and explain their impact on the
development of state and local public policy. (Economics; History; Individuals, Society and Culture)

9BB0A24BF118404B8AB44379EBEBA43B.description:
Explain the organization of state and local governments in Indiana and analyze how they affect the lives of
citizens.

FE61B6DD342442FCAD221B49803B7D8F.description: Explain and evaluate the original purpose and function of the Electoral College and its relevance today.

37886DDA57464FA8A54FC46A01FB0FAA.description:
Summarize the evolution of political parties and their ideologies in the American governmental system and
analyze their functions in elections and government at national, state and local levels of the federal system.
(History; Individuals, Society and Culture)

F812057D70844BA68131C6F70FD7F7BC.description:
Analyze the election of Benjamin Harrison, Indiana’s only president, his approach to the presidency, his
relationship to the legislative branch, and his re-election defeat, considering the effects of party politics and
public opinion.

F77F55CCE7634A71974C680A7C36923E.description:
Explain the electoral process in terms of election laws and election systems on the national, state and local
level.

ABECCF7FCCF0428F8AEA908F91E048FA.description:
Analyze the functions of major departments of the executive branch in the United States and in Indiana.
(Individuals, Society and Culture)

F3314DEA2ACC465190730F2B49FE0BDB.description:
Analyze the functions of the judicial branch of the United States and Indiana governments with emphasis
on the principles of due process, judicial review and an independent judiciary.

5BBE9FDE28904F62B25DBC2275EABA46.description:
Describe the procedures for amending the United States and Indiana Constitutions and analyze why it is so
difficult to amend these Constitutions.

6157EF8D943B4333AB264C93FC9D932C.description: Explain how a bill becomes law in the legislative process of the United States and the state of Indiana.

9EB10B921C914A8FBDADF38604016EB3.description:
Describe the fiscal and monetary policies incorporated by the United States government and Indiana
government and evaluate how they affect individuals, groups and businesses. (Economics)

0967C756DD274C0C95877AC9805FA12B.description:
Explain the relationships among branches of the United States government and Indiana government, which
involve separation and sharing of powers as a means to limited government.

685D2110882B418287FFE620BD188F4A.description:
Compare and contrast the enumerated, implied and denied powers in the United States Constitution and
the Indiana Constitution.

F7C219C7740A49E98A27B6B3E73A0435.description:
Explain the section of Article IV, Section 4, of the United States Constitution which says, “The United States
shall guarantee to every State in the Union a Republican form of government.”

243B9E33788047568C61E67AF6F9C82E.description: Explain the relationship between limited government and a market economy. (Economics)

08EA113FC02649DABA61A9ABAF0D8D4E.description:
Identify and describe provisions of the United States Constitution and the Indiana Constitution that define
and distribute powers and authority of the federal or state government.

48CD4CE459C043E88018D318819CDE09.description:
Explain the constitutional principles of federalism, separation of powers, the system of checks and
balances, republican government or representative democracy, and popular sovereignty; provide examples
of these principles in the governments of the United States and the state of Indiana.

B655326C0FBE46DFAA3E3C4EBB4BC6EA.description:
Analyze the United States Constitution and explain characteristics of government in the United States,
which define it as a federal, presidential, constitutional and representative democracy.

7A3FF1094CEA4CE3AF3D071C807323C7.description:
Explain the history and provide historical and contemporary examples of fundamental principles and values
of American political and civic life, including liberty, security, the common good, justice, equality, law and
order, rights of individuals, diversity, popular sovereignty, and representative democracy. (Individuals,
Society and Culture)

06A8041A0FCD458FA97AC9B19CA4DC92.description:
Using primary documents compare and contrast the ideas of the Federalists and the Anti-Federalists
regarding the respective roles of state and national government on ratification of the United States
Constitution (1787–1788). (History)

B7F68146408B46E1BAA5D8BEA7C49E7F.description:
Explain how a shared American civic identity is based on commitment to foundational ideas in FoundingEra
documents and in core documents of subsequent periods of United States history. (History)

24D28F2F8361408396FA20080D30F6EC.description:
Identify and explain elements of the social contract and natural rights theories in United States founding-era
 documents.

A216B66074EC49C88E050B4E103E0AF3.description:
Explain the history and provide examples of foundational ideas of American government embedded in the
Founding-Era documents such as: natural rights philosophy, social contract, popular sovereignty,
constitutionalism, representative democracy, political factions, federalism, and individual rights.

CDAB09BBB2D04741B7FC45CC24E9B6FB.description:
Analyze and interpret central ideas on government, individual rights, and the common good in founding
documents of the United States.

CDC9BCFAB1304521A5C88C526E57F673.description: Understand the concept of compromise and evaluate its application during the Constitutional Convention.

A63821F293324C9BA3574C731E6753CC.description: Foundations of Government in the United States

B28CD6CD7B24430C9CAAC1A097A7F34A.description:
Evaluate how the United States Constitution establishes majority rule while protecting minority rights and
balances the common good with individual liberties. (History; Individuals, Society and Culture)

2C9F81A72DBB44BAB2BED9A47F7F6185.description:
Evaluate the importance of a written constitution in establishing and maintaining the principles of rule of law
and limited government.

10A41950CA4542AA8C390383F37C76AB.description:
Define and provide examples of constitutionalism, rule of law, limited government, and popular sovereignty
in the United States Constitution and explain the relationship of these constitutional principles to the
protection of the rights of individuals. (History; Individuals, Society and Culture)

95986F5A5C724B65B5A8AC1BE9199F6D.description: Compare and contrast unitary, confederate, and federal systems of government.

99F23571D6AC4B009A4183E067E480C1.description:
Compare and contrast characteristics of limited and unlimited governments and provide historical and
contemporary examples of each type of government.

A987662CF1314989814D64FDBE7B061E.description:
Compare and contrast types of government including direct democracy, monarchy, oligarchy, and
totalitarianism. (History; Individuals, Society and Culture)

CE0B0021E91042E3A1386201463E77CB.description:
Interpret the purposes and functions of government found in the Preamble of the United States
Constitution. (Economics)

28395D4898ED40BB82C8CC2AEE5E9D3F.description: Define the terms and explain the relationship between politics, government, and public policy. (Economics)

82ECEC3724EE4E64B7E17A8522F56BD3.description:
Define civic life, political life, and private life and describe the activities of individuals in each of these
spheres. (Individuals, Society and Culture)

7CDA475D20AD45ED9B2ED35E8073ECE2.description: The Nature of Politics and Government
